response.answer_text: Some authors use simple sentences most of the time (Hemingway). Some authors use long, run-on, compound-complex sentences (D. Defoe). Some authors write in poetry, others in prose. All these types of writings are considered styles of writing. The same information may be handed over, but one person says, “Yes, do it” while another says, “It is time for it to be done, so, yes, have it done now.” If you can recognize a pattern of writing for the author, then that is his/her style (more or less).

A writing style is one person’s voice or the way they convey information. For example, in speech, in response to someone saying ““That shirt is blue,” one person might say, “Yes, it is.” While another person might say sarcastically, “It’s blue, really? I didn’t know that! It’s not like I can see it or anything!” Much like speech, different people have different ways of writing. For example, read a bit of Shakespeare’s writing, then compare it to the writing of your favorite modern author. It has a different feel to it, right? That’s because of the change in style.
